headline: Opinion: Expand school-based health centers for better health, educational results
author: James J. Berrens
sentences: According to a study published in the American Journal of Public Health, SBHCs drive benefits such as improved grade point averages, increased preventatives care, higher rates of high school completion and reduced educational gaps and health disparities.

Whether it’s developing a SBHC in a new community or supporting an existing SBHC to add more services onsite like dental or vision or extending behavioral health capacity, growing Ohio’s SBHC footprint will drive better health and educational results.

This spring, as the governor and state legislature make decisions around investing additional federal COVID relief dollars, expanding the footprint of Ohio’s school-based health centers would be a smart use of these one-time funds.
Here in Hamilton County, Crossroad Health Center is an FQHC that currently provides primary health care services at two SBHCs – William H. Taft Elementary and Rothenberg Preparatory Academy.
Crossroad’s mission is to give honor to Jesus Christ by providing accessible, comprehensive health care in partnership with our patients and community leading to healthy, changed lives.
Prudent use of one-time federal COVID funds for initial capital and start-up expenses will help expand these important services to more Ohio communities, in both urban and rural areas.
Because chronic absenteeism is the result of complex mental, physical, and family health issues, SBHCs play an integral part in strategically addressing attendance problems.
SBHCs are commonly sponsored by community health care providers such as federally qualified health centers (FQHCs), hospitals or local health departments.
Mike DeWine and bipartisan legislative leaders, have previously made significant investments in student wellness and capacity-building at existing SBHCs.
SBHCs provide primary and preventative care services, which many times includes medical, behavioral health and often dental and vision services too.
In a typical SBHC model, a sponsoring entity operates and administers the SBHC and employs or contracts with staff to provide health care services.
In school year 2019, these schools’ SBHCs provided more than a combined 1,800 patient visits for students, staff and community members.
For more than 30 years, school-based health centers in Ohio have improved the health and education outcomes of the students they serve.
Spring is a time for healing and renewal and an opportunity for our state to renew and further support SBHCs in more Ohio communities.

Opinion contributor
The COVID-19 pandemic has been disruptive and devastating for too many, including our school-aged children.
SBHCs are health centers located in or near a school that deliver health services to students (pre-K-12).
If more SBHC dollars become available, Crossroad would compete for funds to bring SBHCs to more schools.
Time will tell what long-term impacts the pandemic will have on our students, families and communities.
Many SBHCs also serve school staff, parents and siblings of students, and other community members.
Additionally, other research has found many links between SBHCs and increased school attendance.
In these cases, SBHCs often stay open beyond normal school hours and during summers.
Ohio is home to more than 85 SBHCs across 25 counties, and that’s a good start.
But there is more to do in support of communities across the entire state.
James J. Berrens is the CEO of Crossroad Heath Center.
